subclusters.subcluster_name: Genetic Program and Epigenetic Regulation Longevity Theory
Phenoptosis and Programmed Death Longevity Theory

theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on IGF-I/Akt/mTORC1 signaling pathway as a key nutrient-sensing and anabolic regulator controlling aging pace.
Describes mTOR, SIRT1, and AMPK nutrient-sensing pathways regulating metabolism and aging.
Details IGF-1 signaling modulation affecting aging and tissue degeneration, linking IGF-1 to nutrient sensing and senescence.
Focuses on insulin/IGF and mTOR pathways and autophagy as nutrient-sensing mechanisms controlling lifespan.
Describes interconnected nutrient sensors including mTOR, AMPK, SIRT1, and IGF1 regulating anabolic/catabolic balance and aging.
Covers GH/IGF-1 axis, mTOR-S6K, AMPK, and sirtuin pathways as nutrient-sensing regulators of longevity.
Shows essential amino acid restriction extends lifespan via TOR signaling reduction, linking diet to nutrient sensing and aging.
Discusses IGF-1 as a growth regulator inversely correlated with longevity, fitting nutrient-sensing and growth signaling theme.
Describes biphasic cardiac IGF1R signaling effects on aging mediated by mTOR and autophagy, linking IGF-1 and nutrient sensing.
Focuses on nutrient sensing pathways including insulin/IGF, TOR, and AMPK regulating metabolic homeostasis and lifespan.
Emphasizes nutrient sensing pathways TOR and insulin/IGF in lifespan regulation and dietary restriction effects.
Describes dietary restriction, IIS, and TOR pathway inhibition as conserved nutrient-sensing mechanisms extending lifespan.
Focuses on pharmacological targeting of nutrient-sensing network (IIS, mTOR) to modulate aging and extend lifespan.
Focuses on sirtuins as NAD-dependent deacetylases mediating calorie restriction effects on metabolism and aging.
Describes SIRT2 deacetylation of FOXO3a under caloric restriction and oxidative stress, linking sirtuins to stress resistance and aging.
Details SIR2 gene role in lifespan extension via genetic regulation of survival and stress resistance.
Describes longevity in growth hormone receptor knockout mice with altered metabolism, consistent with sirtuin and nutrient sensing regulation.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Program and Epigenetic Regulation Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes aging as a genetic program involving biological clocks, hormonal regulation, and telomere shortening.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Program and Epigenetic Regulation Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on programmed epigenetic changes (Type 1 and 2) controlling aging via methylation clocks and gene expression.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Program and Epigenetic Regulation Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Emphasizes genetic regulation of aging via conserved pathways and programmatic cellular maintenance decisions.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Program and Epigenetic Regulation Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Proposes aging as a programmed continuation of development controlled by epigenetic and systemic factors.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Genetic Program and Epigenetic Regulation Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes transcription factor Grainyhead 1 regulating lifespan via insulin signaling and epigenetic modifications.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Phenoptosis and Programmed Death Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Defines aging as phenoptosis, a programmed death process mediated by mitochondria and ROS signaling at multiple biological levels.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Phenoptosis and Programmed Death Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Conceptualizes aging as genetically programmed phenoptosis with evolutionary benefits and temporal scaling of mortality.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Phenoptosis and Programmed Death Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes programmatic hyperfunction and quasi-programs causing senescent pathologies leading to death, fitting phenoptosis concept.
